results.title: And then there were none = Ten little indians
results.creator_credit: Rene Clair, Harry M Popkin and Popular Pictures
results.brief_description: Ten strangers, each with a criminal past, are invited to attend a party on desolate island off the English coast at the request of a mysterious host, Mr Owen. As the group settle into their sojourn, it gradually dawns on them that they have been gathered on the island to be murdered, one by one, as penance for their crimes. It seems that guests are being murdered according the nursery rhyme, “Ten little Indians”, but even knowing what murder is coming next can’t prevent it- the surviving Indians must find the mysterious Mr Owen, masquerading as one of the guests, to stop the deadly cat and mouse game. Cast includes Walter Huston, Louise Hayward, Roland Young and Judith Anderson. Based on the novel by Agatha Christie.

results.title: The Cocoanuts
results.creator_credit: Robert Florey, Joseph Santley, Walter Wanger, James R. Cowan, Monta Bell and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Another hilarious film starring Groucho, Harpo, Zeppo and Chico Marx, ‘Cocoanuts’ is one of the early talkie films and the Marx Brother’s first film. Set in Miami, Groucho Marx plays Hotel Manager, Mr Hammer, struggling to keep his establishment from going under. Hammer’s only paying guest is Mrs Potter (Margaret Dumont), whose daughter Polly (Mary Eaton) is in love with aspiring architect, Bob (Oscar Shaw). Mrs Potter would prefer that Polly marry the respectable Harvey Yates (Cyril Ring); little does she know that he is a jewel thief. Throughout this basic story the four Marx brothers create havoc in their usual slapstick manner, with hilarious results.

results.title: Stage door canteen
results.creator_credit: Frank Borzage, Sol Lesser and Sol Lesser Productions
results.brief_description: At a Stage Door Canteen in Manhattan, three enlisted men on a one-day pass to New York meet and fall in love with three hostesses working there (Cheryl Walker, Marjorie Riordan, Dorothea Kent). This film is noted for its 60 plus celebrities who star as themselves, rather than the love story that provides the backdrop for their appearance. The setting allows for a cavalcade of musical and comedy numbers as well as cameo appearances. Cast also includes William Terry, Lon McCallister and Michael Harrison.

results.title: The Kiss
results.brief_description: Greta Garbo plays a woman accused of adultery and the murder of her husband. Set with a pre-talkies soundtrack this early film of Garbo’s highlights early European conservatism and the impact of social scandal on a young woman determined to maintain her dignity and freedom to follow true love. This collector’s classic edition of the film also features Garbo career highlights including rare fashion show footage, screen-tests and the star’s arrival in the USA.

results.title: Crocodile Dundee: Crocodile Dundee II
results.creator_credit: John Cornell, Rimfire Films, Hoyts and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: This double set features Australia’s highest grossing comedy film, ‘Crocodile Dundee’, and its significantly less successful sequel. ‘Crocodile Dundee’ (Producer: John Cornell, Director: Peter Faiman) A New York reporter is intrigued by stories of an Australian crocodile hunter and accompanies him on a journey through the bush. She entices him back to Manhattan where his easy-going approach to the dangers of life in a big city make him a success in New York society. ‘Crocodile Dundee II’ (Producers: John Cornell, Jane Scott, Director: John Cornell) begins in New York where Dundee now lives with his journalist girlfriend, who he managed to secure in the first film. In order to escape the pursuit of an international drug ring who have murdered her former husband, Dundee and his girlfriend return to the Australian outback where Dundee is well prepared to confront them. Cast includes Paul Hogan, Linda Kozlowski, John Meillon, Mark Blum and David Gulpilil.

results.title: The Butcher boy
results.creator_credit: Neil Jordan, Stephen Woolley, Redmond Morris and Geffen Pictures
results.brief_description: The voice of an adult Francie O’Grady reflects back on his youth. There were three things important to young Francie; his long suffering but mentally unstable mother, his alcoholic Da (Stephen Rea) - “the best music man that ever lived, and his best friend, Joe (Alan Boyle). Francie, clearly the leader in his friendship with blood brother Joe, centers the pair in a fantastic world removed from the reality of their everyday existence in a small Irish town. Set against the backdrop of the Cold War and the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis, Communism is as much a contributing factor to Francie’s cynicism towards the world as are aliens, and Mrs Nugent, mother of the young boy who threatens to be “better” friends with Joe. Inhabiting Francie’s fantasy world is Our Lady, controversially portrayed by Sinead O’Connor, who speaks to Francie in times of need. Francie and Joe live in a world influenced by popular culture and their rural environment. Thus, their days are marked by comics, flash bars, fishing, and American films. Francie’s questionable antics land him in a boys home, and the nature of these antics, as they are transferred stylistically into stagey cartoonish sets, render the scenes with a disturbing, puzzling and cruel aura. When Francie returns to the village he is outraged to find that a lot has changed. He begins a job assisting a local butcher who slaughters pigs, earning him the eponymous title, Butcher Boy. Pigs are a central theme throughout the film, and one which inspires the final disturbing scenes. Cast includes Stephen Rea, Fiona Shaw and Eamonn Owens (Francie). Adapted from the book by Patrick McCabe.

results.title: Thieves like us
results.creator_credit: Robert Altman, Jerry Bick and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Keith Carradine is cast as Bowie, one of three criminals who escape from prison and after a period of good behaviour, fall back into crime by committing a series of bank robberies. In typical ‘Bonnie and Clyde’ (303821) fashion, Bowie falls in love with Keechie (Shelley Duvall), the daughter of the farmer who helped them escape, and she too joins them in their escapades. Bowie and Keechie plan to escape to Mexico, but their dreams for a new start are doomed by the behaviour of the other two criminals, and the couple are destined for tragedy. This remake of the ‘They live by night’ (1948), is based on the novel by Edward Anderson. Cast includes Keith Carradine, Shelley Duvall, John Schuck, Bert Remsen and Louise Fletcher.

results.title: Night on earth
results.brief_description: This film by the talented independent director, Jim Jarmusch, is a collection of five vignettes each taking place in the confines of a taxi ride. Covering one night on earth, the stories occur simultaneously in five different cities and five different time zones: Los Angeles, New York City, Paris, London and Helsinki. Highlights include Roberto Benigni as the Roman taxi driver who recounts his past sexual exploits to a priest who is dying of a heart-attack in the back seat. In the New York scene a novice East German taxi driver (Armin Mueller-Stahl) has trouble with the foot pedals and his passenger ends up driving himself to Brooklyn. Cast includes Gena Rowlands, Rosie Perez, Giancarlo Esposito, Winona Ryder, Beatrice Dalle.

results.title: Stranger than paradise
results.creator_credit: Jim Jarmusch, Sara Driver and Cinesthesia Productions
results.brief_description: Jim Jarmusch’s debut feature is a dead pan masterpiece, utilising to great effect its low key performances, static camera movement and grungy, sparse locations. Shot in high contrast black and white by Tom Decillo (who went on to direct ‘Johnny Suede’ and ‘Living in Oblivion’), this quirky road movie presents a unique outsiders view of America and the characters that inhabit its fringes. Structured as a series of three vignettes spaning New York, Cleveland and Florida, ‘Stranger than Paradise’ stars John Lurie (who also wrote the music) as Wille, a laidback hipster whose meandering lifestyle is briefly disrupted when his Hungarian, teenage cousin (Eszter Balint) comes to stay. The films cool, episodic style, slipping casually between melancholy and off the wall humour became a distinct Jarmusch trade mark, fine tuned in later films such as ‘Down by law’, ‘Mystery Train’, ‘Night on earth’ and ‘Dead man’. Cast also includes Richard Edson. (Awards: Winner of the Cannes 1984 Camera d’Or for Best First Feature)

results.title: Leo Tolstoy's Anna Karenina
results.creator_credit: Bernard Rose, Bruce Davey and ICON
results.brief_description: This adaptation of the Leo Tolstoy masterpiece, “Anna Karenin”, is noted for its stunning cinematography of the foggy Russian landscape. The screenplay is a faithful but abridged version of the novel set in 1880s Russia. The heroine, Anna (Sophie Marceau), is not happy in her marriage to the staid Karenin (James Fox), despite the joy she finds in their son. When she meets Count Vronsky (Sean Bean) in Moscow, where she goes to sort out the marriage problems of her brother, her life is turned upside-down. Their passionate affair causes her to lose her standing in society, being an unfaithful woman, to lose her son and eventually to lose the happiness she so desperately craved. The story is a tragic reminder of the downfall of a woman who dares to rebel against the rules of society. This affair is paralleled by the romance between Levin (Alfred Molina), the narrator of the story who is said to represent Tolstoy, and the young Kitty (Mia Kirshner), who had been in love with Vronsky until Anna captured his attentions. In English with occasional Russian dialogue subtitled in English.
